raw_text:
Bond game fails to shake or stir
 
 For gaming fans, the word GoldenEye evokes excited memories not only of the James Bond revival flick of 1995, but also the classic shoot-em-up that accompanied it and left N64 owners glued to their consoles for many an hour.
 
 Adopting that hallowed title somewhat backfires on this new game, for it fails to deliver on the promise of its name and struggles to generate the original's massive sense of fun. This however is not a sequel, nor does it relate to the GoldenEye film. You are the eponymous renegade spy, an agent who deserts to the Bond world's extensive ranks of criminal masterminds, after being deemed too brutal for MI6. Your new commander-in-chief is the portly Auric Goldfinger, last seen in 1964, but happily running around bent on world domination. With a determination to justify its name which is even less convincing than that of Tina Turner's similarly-titled theme song, the game literally gives the player a golden eye following an injury, which enables a degree of X-ray vision.
 
 Rogue Agent signals its intentions by featuring James Bond initially and proceeding to kill him off within moments, squashed by a plummeting helicopter. The notion is of course to add a novel dark edge to a 007 game, but the premise simply does not get the juices flowing like it needs to.
 
 Recent Bond games like Nightfire and Everything Or Nothing were very competent and did a fine job of capturing the sense of flair, invention and glamour of the film franchise. This title lacks that aura, and when the Bond magic shines through, it feels like a lucky accident. The central problem is that the gameplay just is not good enough. Quite aside from the bizarre inability to jump, the even more bizarre glaring graphical bugs and dubious enemy AI, the levels simply are not put together with much style or imagination. Admittedly the competition has been tough, even in recent weeks, with the likes of Halo 2 and Half Life 2 triumphing in virtually every department. What the game is good at is enveloping you in noisy, dynamic scenes of violent chaos. As is the trend of late, you are made to feel like you are in the midst of a really messy and fraught encounter. Sadly that sense of action is outweighed by the difficulty of navigating and battling within the chaos, meaning that frustration is often the outcome. And irregular save points mean you have to backtrack each time you are killed. A minute red dot passes for a crosshair, although the collision-detection is so suspect that the difficulties of aiming weapons are compensated for. Shooting enemies from a distance can be tricky, and you will not always know you have picked them off, since dead enemies vanish literally before they have fully hit the floor, and they do so in some woefully uninspiring death animations. It is perhaps indicative of a lack of confidence that the game maker's allow you several different weapons almost immediately and throw you quickly into raging firefights - no time is risked with a measured build-up.
 
 By far the most satisfying element of the game is seeing old favourites like Dr No, Goldfinger, hat-fiend Oddjob and crazed Russian sex beast Xenia Onatopp resurrected after all these years, and with their faces rendered in an impressively recognisable fashion.
 
 There is a real thrill from doing battle with these legendary villains, and it is a testament to the power of the Bond universe that they can cut such a dash. But the in-game niggles, combined with a story and presentation that just do not feel sufficiently well thought-through, will make this a disappointment for most. Diehard fans of Bond will probably find enough here to make it a worthwhile purchase and try to ignore the failings. The game is weak, not completely unplayable. Then again, 007 fanatics may also take umbrage at the cavalier blending of characters from different eras. Given James Bond's healthy pedigree in past games, there is every reason to hope that this is just a blip, a commendable idea that just has not worked, that will be rectified when the character inevitably makes his return.
 
 GoldenEye: Rogue Agent is out now
llama3.2:1b:
Bond game fails to shake or stir due to poor gameplay and unimpressive design. The game struggles with jumping mechanics, graphical bugs, and dubious enemy AI, making it frustrating to play. Irregular save points lead to backtracking, which can be a major setback. The story and presentation feel unsatisfactorily well-thought-out, with a disconnect between the game's title and its actual execution.

The game lacks flair, invention, and glamour of previous Bond titles like Nightfire and Everything Or Nothing, instead relying on noisy, dynamic scenes of violence without much style or imagination. The gameplay is weak, with a focus on combat rather than exploration or puzzle-solving, leading to a sense of messiness and frustration.
llama3.2:3b: GoldenEye: Rogue Agent fails to deliver on its promise of fun and instead struggles with poor gameplay mechanics, including graphical bugs and difficulty in navigating chaotic levels. The game's inability to replicate the sense of flair and glamour of previous Bond games makes it feel like a disappointment, but diehard fans may find enough to make it a worthwhile purchase.
gemma2:2b: This game fails to capture the fun and flair of the original "GoldenEye" due to lackluster gameplay and questionable production choices.  The game features a poor shooting system, frustrating navigation, uninspiring enemy AI, and numerous bugs. Despite reintroducing classic villains in an impressive fashion, the core gameplay remains weak, leading to frustration for players seeking a genuine Bond experience. Diehard fans will likely find some enjoyment here despite its shortcomings.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Bond game fails to capture excitement for fans. Gameplay struggles with X-ray vision and other graphical bugs. Central issue is difficulty of navigating and battling in chaotic scenes, with few options. Game makers avoid traditional 007 games but fail to find strong matches in classic Bond franchises. Game can't match old favorites like Dr No, Goldfinger, Oddjob, Xenia Onatopp or notorious villains' faces.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The new game fails to capitalize on the Bond franchise's popularity and offers an inferior experience compared to past installments. It introduces unexpected elements like a golden eye but struggles with gameplay mechanics and graphics, leading to frustration rather than excitement. The inclusion of classic villains provides a minor satisfaction but detracts from the overall quality of the game. Despite its limitations, it may appeal to fans who can overlook the issues for nostalgic reasons.
qwen2.5:3b: GoldenEye: Rogue Agent fails to deliver on its promise of fun and excitement akin to its predecessor. Despite featuring classic Bond villains like Goldfinger and Oddjob, the game suffers from poor gameplay mechanics, including bugs, unintuitive AI, and graphical issues. While it rekindles fans' memories with revived iconic characters, its disjointed story and lackluster narrative prevent a strong overall experience. Fans of 007 may find enough nostalgic content to enjoy, but for most others, the game is weak and not worth purchasing due to significant flaws in execution.

smollm:1.7b:
GoldenEye: Rogue Agent is a 2019 action-adventure game developed by Rare and published by Nintendo Switch. It was released on September 3, 2019 for the Nintendo Switch.

**Story**

The game takes place in the GoldenEye era, where James Bond (voiced by Javier Bardem) is tasked with stopping a group of rogue agents from taking over the world. The game follows Bond's journey as he travels to various locations around the world, including London, Paris, and Tokyo, to stop the rogue agents and prevent them from destroying the world.

The story is divided into several chapters, each set in a different location during the GoldenEye era. Each chapter features a new set of characters, including Bond's friends and allies, as well as new villains and enemies to battle.

**Gameplay**

GoldenEye: Rogue Agent features a mix of action-adventure gameplay and stealth elements. The game is divided into two main modes: "Action" and "Stealth". In the Action mode, Bond must use his skills and gadgets to take down the rogue agents, while in the Stealth mode, Bond must sneak past them undetected.

The game features a variety of combat systems, including sword fights, gunfights, and melee combat. Bond can also use his gadgets, such as the Deux-Pond and the Deux-Lantern, to take down enemies.

**Characters**

Bond's friends and allies in the game include:

* Ian Fleming (voiced by James O'Reilly): Bond's trusted friend and confidant.
* Tatiana Maslupova (voiced by Saoirse Ronan): Bond's partner in crime-fighting.
* Yves Saint Laurent (voiced by Paul McGann): A former French spy who becomes Bond's ally.
* Victor Laszlo (voiced by John Krasinski): A British agent who becomes Bond's friend and ally.

**Visuals and Soundtrack**

GoldenEye: Rogue Agent features a vibrant, colorful art style that pays homage to the GoldenEye era. The game is set in various locations around the world, including London, Paris, Tokyo, and New York City.

The soundtrack, composed by John Krasinski, features a mix of classic Bond themes and new tracks inspired by the game's story.

**Reception**

GoldenEye: Rogue Agent received generally positive reviews from critics, praising its engaging storyline, challenging gameplay, and stunning visuals. The game was praised for its attention to detail, with fans appreciating the game's nods to the GoldenEye era and its faithful portrayal of Bond's character.

However, some players felt that the game lacked a strong narrative focus, with some chapters feeling more like side quests than main story arcs. Additionally, some critics noted that the game's gameplay was not as challenging as some other action-adventure games in the genre.

**Conclusion**

GoldenEye: Rogue Agent is a fun and engaging action-adventure game that pays homage to the GoldenEye era. While it may not be perfect, the game's attention to detail, its strong gameplay, and its stunning visuals make it a enjoyable experience for fans of the genre.

Rogue Agent is an attempt at reimagining James Bond with a portly character and a golden eye effect, setting the tone through a departure from MI6's brutal approach. The game follows James Bond initially, leading to a challenging narrative and graphical inconsistencies, lacking flair or innovation. It returns familiar Bond villains but struggles with consistent gameplay. While it features old characters and an engaging story, its graphics issues and mechanics make it a poor experience overall.
tinyllama:1.1b: BoND game fails to shake or stir for gamers and struggles to generate excitement due to its failure to deliver on promises of the classic shoot-em-up that accompanied it, and struggling to generate originality in its sequel. While its hero, Agent James Bond, is rejuvenated after years of absence from the Bond world, this new game does not match the level of excellence seen in previous titles like NiGhftire or EverythingOrNothing. This is evident through a lackluster storyline and gameplay mechanics that fail to captivate gamers. Despite being an attempt to replicate the brilliance of Bond's films, it fails to produce an immersive experience for players.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The game fails to shake or stir because its core concept and mechanics are not engaging enough and it struggles to deliver on the promise of being a 007 game. This does not make sense, given the franchise's history of releasing high-quality games with memorable characters and environments, but it underscores the lackluster nature of this latest title. The developers should take a more modest approach in terms of gameplay and presentation, focusing on giving the player a sense of fun and excitement rather than pushing the boundaries of what is possible within a 007 game. This will likely result in a more satisfying and memorable experience for fans of the franchise, but it may also prompt some to question the value of investing time and effort into this particular title.
phi:2.7b: The game "GoldenEye: Rogue Agent" fails to deliver on the promise of its name and struggles to generate massive fun due to the game's weak gameplay, glaring graphical bugs, questionable enemy AI, and lack of imagination in level design. While there are some satisfying moments such as battling with legendary villains from the Bond universe, overall, it is a disappointment for most players. However, die-hard fans may still find it worth playing and ignoring its shortcomings. The game's weaknesses include a blurring of characters from different eras and a lack of confidence in aiming weapons accurately.

The article concludes that while the game has its moments, it is not a complete success and may have been better served by more careful planning and development.
hermes3:3b: GoldenEye: Rogue Agent game fails to capture fun of original, lacks good gameplay, and struggles with issues like jumping, graphical bugs, enemy AI.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: GoldenEye: Rogue Agent is a James Bond game that fails to live up to its name and the expectations of its predecessor and the film franchise. It adopts the title somewhat backfiring by adopting a dark edge with killing off James Bond in moments but lacks the fun and flair that made the original GoldenEye so memorable. The gameplay, levels, and presentation are lacking style and imagination, causing frustration for players despite some satisfying elements featuring classic Bond villains. Diehard fans might still find it worthwhile, but overall, it is a disappointment compared to past Bond games like Nightfire and Everything Or Nothing.
chatgpt-4o-latest: GoldenEye: Rogue Agent fails to live up to the legacy of its namesake, lacking the fun and polish of the original N64 classic. The game takes a novel approach by casting the player as a rogue MI6 agent working for villains like Goldfinger, but its dark premise falls flat. Gameplay suffers from poor design, graphical bugs, weak AI, and frustrating mechanics, including awkward navigation and irregular save points. While the game delivers chaotic action, it lacks the style and imagination of recent top-tier shooters like Halo 2 and Half-Life 2. The most enjoyable aspect is the return of classic Bond villains, rendered with impressive detail, but the overall experience is underwhelming. Diehard Bond fans may find some enjoyment, but the game ultimately disappoints, feeling like a misstep rather than a worthy addition to the franchise.
stablelm2:1.6b:
The game "GoldenEye: Rogue Agent" fails to meet expectations and lacks the fun and glamour associated with the James Bond franchise. It introduces a new protagonist while keeping James Bond as a supporting character, which does not resonate well with players. The gameplay is marred by various issues such..
As expected, GoldenEye: Rogue Agent is unable to shake or stir the excitement of gaming fans who remember the original GoldenEye game, which was an iconic entry in the James Bond franchise. Despite being named after the film and its associated shoot-em-up, this adaptation falls short of meeting the level of fun, innovation, and flair that was present in previous games.

The main issue is that "GoldenEye: Rogue Agent" fails to deliver on its title promise and struggles to provide the same sense of excitement as the earlier game. The game offers numerous weapons almost immediately, which forces players into action from the start without giving them time to acclimate themselves with their playstyle. It is a lack of cautious build-up that keeps players feeling rushed throughout the game.

Another major flaw in "GoldenEye: Rogue Agent" is its combat system, which is deemed as difficult and confusing by reviewers. Enemies' animations are uninspiring and make aiming challenging from distance, while enemies vanish before reaching the floor after being killed, leading to confusion amongst players.

The game does offer a few redeeming qualities; one of them includes featuring popular Bond villains like Dr. No, Auric Goldfinger, Oddjob, and Xenia Onatopp. These characters' faces are rendered in an impressive, recognisable fashion that provides some satisfaction for diehard fans of the franchise.

Unfortunately, despite these compensations, "GoldenEye: Rogue Agent" falls short of meeting expectations and creating a lasting impact on players. It lacks the depth and complexity needed to satisfy fans of the James Bond universe, resulting in disappointment among those who played it.

In conclusion, while "GoldenEye: Rogue Agent" may offer a chance for diehard fans to revisit their favourite Bond villains, it's not enough to make it an enjoyable gaming experience. As such, this game is considered weak and not entirely playable by all players, though diehard Bond enthusiasts might find some satisfaction in trying it out. Overall, "GoldenEye: Rogue Agent" falls short of providing the excitement and fun that fans of the franchise expect from their James Bond games.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
GoldenEye: Rogue Agent, named after the iconic James Bond game and film, fails to deliver on its promise. The game places players as a disgruntled MI6 agent who defects to criminal mastermind Goldfinger's team, but this twist lacks the intended impact due to poor execution. Players can't jump, encounter graphical glitches, and deal with uninspired enemy AI, making navigation challenging and frustrating. Despite dynamic combat scenes, the game is marred by difficult navigation and unsatisfying aiming mechanics.

The most engaging aspect of Rogue Agent is encountering classic Bond villains like Dr. No, Goldfinger, Oddjob, and Xenia Onatopp, rendered in impressive detail. However, the story and presentation feel underdeveloped, detracting from the overall experience for most players. Diehard fans may still find value in the game, but it's a weak entry that leaves much to be desired compared to recent Bond games and competitors like Halo 2 and Half Life 2. The developers' confidence is evident in their swift introduction of various weapons, but this hastiness contributes to the game's shortcomings. This release is currently available.
